var_drug_ann.Notes: Therapy-induced leukopenia occurred in 9/24 (37.5%) CT, 2/2 (100%) TT, and 1/123 (0.8%) CC patients. Leukopenia was significantly associated with the T allele (OR 20.41, 95% CI 7.84–53.13; P < 0.00001) with sensitivity 91.67% and specificity 89.05%. All leukopenia developed within 60 days after therapy initiation or dose increase.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotypes CT + TT are associated with increased risk of leukopenia with azathioprine in patients with autoimmune hepatitis and related cirrhosis as compared to genotype CC.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:Autoimmune Hepatitis, Disease:Primary Biliary Cholangitis-autoimmune hepatitis overlap syndrome
Citations: Therapy-induced leukopenia was observed in 9/24 (37.5%) patients with the CT allele and 2/2 (100%) patients with the TT allele. However, only one patient with wild-type homozygote allele experienced leukopenia. All cases of leukopenia developed within the first 60 days following therapy initiation or dose increase.

When evaluated by rs116855232 genotype, leukopenia was significantly associated with the T allele [P < 0.00001, odds ratio = 20.41; 95% CI (7.84, 53.13)], with the sensitivity and specificity of 91.67 and 89.05%, respectively (Table 3).
We found that a NUDT15 polymorphism (rs116855232) was significantly associated with AZA-induced leukopenia in Chinese patients with AIH and related cirrhosis.

var_drug_ann.Notes: Among 93 patients in biochemical remission on maintenance therapy, median azathioprine maintenance dosage was 1.23 (0.95, 1.53) mg·kg−1·d−1 for rs116855232 CC and 0.96 (0.83, 1.19) mg·kg−1·d−1 for CT (P = 0.028). One TT patient maintained therapy at 0.2 mg·kg−1·d−1 but numbers were too small for significance.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype CT is associated with decreased azathioprine maintenance dose in patients with autoimmune hepatitis and related cirrhosis as compared to genotype CC.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:Autoimmune Hepatitis, Disease:Primary Biliary Cholangitis-autoimmune hepatitis overlap syndrome
Citations: In total, 93 patients have achieved biochemical remission and began maintenance therapy as of February 2018. The AZA dose did not significantly differ between CC and CT genotypes (*P* = 0.22) when evaluated with a clinical therapeutic dose of 1.0 mg ⋅ kg^−1^ ⋅ d^−1^. However, the median maintenance dosages for patients with the *NUDT15* CC and CT genotypes were 1.23 (0.95, 1.53) mg ⋅ kg^−1^ ⋅ d^−1^ and 0.96 (0.83, 1.19) mg ⋅ kg^−1^ ⋅ d^−1^, respectively (*P* = 0.028) ([Figure 2](#F2)).
The median maintenance dosages for patients with rs116855232 CC and CT genotypes were 1.23 (0.95, 1.53) mg ⋅ kg−1 ⋅ d−1 and 0.96 (0.83, 1.19) mg ⋅ kg−1 ⋅ d−1, respectively (P = 0.028).
For patients with the heterozygous variants, low-dose AZA (0.96 mg ⋅ kg^−1^ ⋅ d^−1^) is safe for maintaining remission and achieving efficacy comparable to that observed in wild-type patients.

var_drug_ann.Notes: 6-thioguanine nucleotide (6-TGN) concentrations were higher in patients with rs116855232 CT versus CC genotypes: 276.6 (150.9, 501.0) vs 145.3 (87.4, 199.0) pmol/8*10^8 RBC (P = 0.002). The median ratio of azathioprine dose to 6-TGN concentration was 0.007 (0.006, 0.015) for CC and 0.005 (0.003, 0.006) for CT (P = 0.001).
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype CT is associated with increased concentrations of 6-thioguanine nucleotide during azathioprine therapy in patients with autoimmune hepatitis and related cirrhosis as compared to genotype CC.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:Autoimmune Hepatitis, Disease:Primary Biliary Cholangitis-autoimmune hepatitis overlap syndrome
Citations: 6-Thioguanine nucleotide concentrations were significantly higher in the patients of NUDT15 CT genotype [P = 0.002, 276.6(150.9, 501.0) vs. 145.3(87.4, 199.0) pmol/8∗108 RBC] (Figure 1 and Supplementary Table S1).
6-Thioguanine nucleotide concentrations for patients with rs116855232 CC and CT genotypes were 145.3(87.4, 199.0) pmol/8 ∗108 RBC and 276.6(150.9, 501.0) pmol/8∗108 RBC, respectively (P = 0.002).

The ratio of AZA dose to 6-TGN concentration for the patients was compared between NUDT15 CC and CT genotypes and the results showed that patients with NUDT15 CT genotypes had much lower values (P = 0.013) (Figure 3).

var_drug_ann.Notes: Among 93 patients who achieved biochemical remission, 75 (80.6%) were CC and 17 (18.3%) were CT. No difference in percentage achieving biochemical remission (P = 0.361) or median time to biochemical remission (3.0 vs 4.0 months; P = 0.161) was observed between CC and CT genotypes.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotype CT is not associated with response to azathioprine, assessed as biochemical remission, in patients with autoimmune hepatitis and related cirrhosis as compared to genotype CC.
var_drug_ann.Population Phenotypes or diseases: Disease:Autoimmune Hepatitis, Disease:Primary Biliary Cholangitis-autoimmune hepatitis overlap syndrome
Citations: Among the 93 patients who reached biochemical remission, 75 (80.6%) were wild-type homozygotes, and 17 (18.3%) subjects were heterozygotes. No differences were observed in the percentage of patients who achieved biochemical remission (P = 0.361) or the median time to biochemical remission (P = 0.161; 3.0 vs. 4.0 months, respectively) between the genotypes.

In total, 93 patients have achieved biochemical remission and began maintenance therapy as of February 2018. The AZA dose did not significantly differ between CC and CT genotypes (P = 0.22) when evaluated with a clinical therapeutic dose of 1.0 mg ⋅ kg−1 ⋅ d−1.

var_drug_ann.Notes: TPMT*3C rs1142345 alleles were observed in four subjects (3 TC heterozygotes, 1 CC homozygote). Overall TPMT risk allele frequency was 1.7%.
var_drug_ann.Sentence: Genotypes TC + CC of rs1142345 are not associated with risk of leukopenia with azathioprine in patients with autoimmune hepatitis and related cirrhosis as compared to genotype TT.

The variant allelic frequency of rs116855232 was 9.4%, while *TPMT∗3C* alleles were only observed in four subjects including 3 patients who were heterozygotes (TC) and 1 patient who was homozygous (CC).”

summary:
Study question and design: This single-center retrospective pharmacogenetic study evaluated whether NUDT15 R139C (rs116855232) and TPMT*3C (rs1142345) variants predict azathioprine (AZA)–induced leukopenia and influence tolerated AZA dose in Chinese patients with autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) and AIH–PBC overlap, many with cirrhosis. Population and treatment: • 149 consecutive Chinese patients with definite/probable AIH or AIH–PBC variant syndrome treated with AZA ≥3 months at West China Hospital (2013–2017). • 70 had AIH–PBC overlap; 81 had cirrhosis at AZA start. • AZA introduced after steroids per EASL guidance; target maintenance 1–2 mg/kg/day. • CBCs closely monitored; leukopenia defined as WBC <3×10⁹/L, or progressive worsening if pre‑existing.
• 13 patients had leukopenia already before AZA (baseline WBC ~2.5×10⁹/L). Genotyping and metabolite measurement: • NUDT15 rs116855232 (C>T; p.Arg139Cys) and TPMT*3C rs1142345 (T>C; p.Leu125Leu) genotyped by PCR + Sanger sequencing. • 6-thioguanine nucleotide (6‑TGN) in RBCs measured by HPLC in 61 patients. Genotype frequencies: • NUDT15: CC 82.6% (123/149), CT 16.1% (24/149), TT 1.3% (2/149); T-allele frequency 9.4%. • TPMT*3C: 3 heterozygotes (TC) and 1 homozygote (CC); risk allele frequency ~1.7%. Incidence and timing of leukopenia: • Overall AZA-induced leukopenia occurred in 12/149 (8.1%). • All leukopenia episodes developed within 60 days of AZA initiation or dose escalation. • No significant differences in baseline age, sex, liver function, disease severity, cirrhosis, splenomegaly, or baseline WBC between those with and without leukopenia. Association of NUDT15 with leukopenia: • Leukopenia by NUDT15 genotype: – CC: 1/123 (0.8%). – CT: 9/24 (37.5%). – TT: 2/2 (100%). • Strong association between T allele and leukopenia: – OR 20.41 (95% CI 7.84–53.13), P < 0.00001. – Dominant model (CT+TT vs CC): OR 89.47 (95% CI 10.78–742.53), P < 0.0001. – Recessive model (TT vs CC+CT): OR 65.48 (95% CI 2.95–1454.21), P = 0.008. • Predictive performance of carrying at least one T allele: sensitivity 91.67%, specificity 89.05%. • Among NUDT15 variant carriers (CT+TT), 11/26 (42.3%) developed AZA-induced leukopenia. • One TT patient with coexisting TPMT wt/risk developed life‑threatening grade 4 myelosuppression within 4 weeks at ~1.1 mg/kg/day; AZA was stopped and mycophenolate mofetil used thereafter. The other TT patient required dose reduction from 0.9 to 0.2 mg/kg/day. Association of TPMT*3C with leukopenia: • No significant association between TPMT*3C genotype and leukopenia (P = 0.283). • Very low allele frequency in this Chinese cohort, consistent with prior Asian data; TPMT explained little of the leukopenia risk. NUDT15, 6‑TGN, and maintenance dose: • 6‑TGN levels (61 patients): – Median (overall): 149.1 pmol/8×10⁸ RBC (range 49.7–1583.4). – NUDT15 CC: 145.3 (87.4–199.0) pmol/8×10⁸ RBC. – NUDT15 CT: 276.6 (150.9–501.0) pmol/8×10⁸ RBC. – P = 0.002 → heterozygotes accumulate significantly more active metabolite at comparable doses. • Among 93 patients in biochemical remission on maintenance AZA: – NUDT15 CC median maintenance dose: 1.23 (0.95–1.53) mg/kg/day. – NUDT15 CT median maintenance dose: 0.96 (0.83–1.19) mg/kg/day. – P = 0.028 → heterozygotes tolerate and require lower AZA doses. • Dose/6‑TGN ratio (AZA dose per unit 6‑TGN) was significantly lower in CT vs CC (0.005 vs 0.007, P = 0.013), reinforcing that CT carriers generate more 6‑TGN per mg of AZA. • 6‑TGN concentration itself did not differ significantly between patients with and without leukopenia (P = 0.149) and was not associated with gender, AZA maintenance dose, or cirrhosis severity. Baseline leukopenia subgroup: • 13 patients started AZA with pre‑existing leukopenia (median WBC 2.48×10⁹/L); – Only 1 was NUDT15 CT; none showed progressive leukopenia on AZA. – Only one stopped AZA due to gastrointestinal side effects, not marrow toxicity. – Median maintenance dose was 1.13 (0.94–1.60) mg/kg/day. • Suggests that, in NUDT15 wild-type patients, pre‑treatment leukopenia from cirrhosis/hypersplenism does not necessarily preclude safe AZA use at standard doses, though this finding needs prospective validation. Biochemical efficacy and NUDT15: • Among 93 patients achieving biochemical remission: – 75 (80.6%) were NUDT15 CC; 17 (18.3%) were CT. – No significant difference in remission rates by genotype (P = 0.361) or time to remission (median 3.0 vs 4.0 months; P = 0.161). • Thus, lowering AZA dose in NUDT15 heterozygotes to avoid leukopenia does not appear to compromise biochemical control in this cohort. Clinical and pharmacogenomic implications: • In this Chinese AIH/AIH–PBC population, NUDT15 R139C—but not TPMT*3C—is the main pharmacogenetic determinant of AZA‑induced leukopenia and tolerated dose. • NUDT15 T‑allele carriers have markedly higher risk of early leukopenia and accumulate more 6‑TGN at any given AZA dose. • For NUDT15 CT patients with AIH or AIH–PBC: – Use a lower AZA maintenance dose ~1 mg/kg/day (or less) as a default target. – Intensively monitor counts in first 2 months; most leukopenia events occur early. • For NUDT15 TT patients, very low starting doses (e.g., 0.1–0.2 mg/kg/day) or alternative immunosuppressants should be strongly considered, given near-universal severe myelosuppression at standard doses. • In East Asian settings, NUDT15 genotyping has higher clinical utility than TPMT for thiopurine safety; nonetheless, combined TPMT+NUDT15 testing is advisable because rare combined defects can be catastrophically toxic. • Standard AZA doses may still be appropriate in patients with cirrhosis or hypersplenism-related leukopenia if they are NUDT15 wild-type, but prospective data are needed. Limitations: • Single-center, modest sample size, rare TT and TPMT*3C variants; confidence intervals are wide for some genotype strata. • Only rs116855232 and TPMT*3C were tested; rarer functional variants may have been missed. • 6‑TGN measured in only ~41% of patients. Overall conclusion: NUDT15 rs116855232 is a strong predictor of AZA-induced leukopenia and dose tolerance in Chinese patients with AIH and AIH–PBC overlap, outperforming TPMT*3C. Heterozygous NUDT15 carriers can generally be treated safely and effectively with lower AZA doses (~1 mg/kg/day), and even in patients with cirrhosis or prior leukopenia, AZA need not be contraindicated if NUDT15 is wild-type. Routine pre‑treatment NUDT15 (and TPMT) genotyping should be incorporated into thiopurine prescribing for this population.
title: NUDT15 Polymorphism Confer Increased Susceptibility to Thiopurine-Induced Leukopenia in Patients With Autoimmune Hepatitis and Related Cirrhosis

var_pheno_ann.Notes: T risk allele in NUDT15 rs116855232 was significantly associated with azathioprine-induced leukopenia in Chinese AIH and related cirrhosis patients (P < 0.00001, OR = 20.41; 95% CI 7.84–53.13). 12/149 patients developed leukopenia, and the variant allele frequency was 9.4%.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: rs116855232 T Is Associated with increased risk of Leukopenia when treated with azathioprine in people with Autoimmune hepatitis and related cirrhosis.
Citations: “Twelve patients developed leukopenia, and this adverse drug reaction was significantly associated with the T risk allele in NUDT15 [P < 0.00001, odds ratio = 20.41; 95% confidence interval (CI) (7.84, 53.13)], with the sensitivity and specificity of 91.67 and 89.05%, respectively.”

“Our results found that the rs116855232 but not the rs1142345 genotype was significantly associated with AZA-induced leukopenia and the maintenance dose in Chinese patients with AIH and related cirrhosis.”
“We found that a NUDT15 polymorphism (rs116855232) was significantly associated with AZA-induced leukopenia in Chinese patients with AIH and related cirrhosis.”

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Therapy-induced leukopenia was observed in 9/24 (37.5%) patients with the rs116855232 CT genotype compared with 1/123 (0.8%) in rs116855232 CC genotype carriers. All leukopenia occurred within 60 days of therapy initiation or dose increase.

Citations: Therapy-induced leukopenia was observed in 9/24 (37.5%) patients with the CT allele and 2/2 (100%) patients with the TT allele. However, only one patient with wild-type homozygote allele experienced leukopenia. All cases of leukopenia developed within the first 60 days following therapy initiation or dose increase.

Our results found that the rs116855232 but not the rs1142345 genotype was significantly associated with AZA-induced leukopenia and the maintenance dose in Chinese patients with AIH and related cirrhosis.
We found that a NUDT15 polymorphism (rs116855232) was significantly associated with AZA-induced leukopenia in Chinese patients with AIH and related cirrhosis.

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Leukopenia occurred in 2/2 (100%) patients with rs116855232 TT genotype. One TT patient experienced lethal grade 4 myelosuppression within 4 weeks on 1.09 mg·kg−1·d−1 azathioprine and required discontinuation; the other TT patient developed leukopenia at 0.9 mg·kg−1·d−1, improved after dose reduction to 0.2 mg·kg−1·d−1.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: rs116855232 TT Is Associated with increased risk of Leukopenia when treated with azathioprine in people with Autoimmune hepatitis and related cirrhosis.
Citations: Therapy-induced leukopenia was observed in 9/24 (37.5%) patients with the CT allele and 2/2 (100%) patients with the TT allele. However, only one patient with wild-type homozygote allele experienced leukopenia. All cases of leukopenia developed within the first 60 days following therapy initiation or dose increase. … One patient with the TT genotype experienced lethal levels of myelosuppression in the first 4 weeks of remission induction with a 1.09 mg ⋅ kg−1 ⋅ d−1 prescription and reached the diagnostic criteria for grade 4 myelosuppression; this patient also carried a TPMTwt/risk genotype. … The other patient with the TT genotype was reduced to a 0.2 mg ⋅ kg−1 ⋅ d−1 prescription after the WBC count from 5.29 × 10^9/L dropped to 1.94 × 10^9/L at the 0.9 mg ⋅ kg−1 ⋅ d−1 prescription; also, WBC counts gradually increased to a satisfactory value (3–4.5 × 10^9/L) after the dosage adjustment.

The aim of this study was to investigate the influence of NUDT15 R139C and thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TPMT) on azathioprine (AZA) induced leukopenia in patients with autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) and related cirrhosis. … Therefore, NUDT15 polymorphism is significantly associated with thiopurine-induced leukopenia in Chinese patients with AIH and related cirrhosis. Adjusting the AZA dosage should be considered in patients according to the NUDT15 R139C genotypes.
We found that a NUDT15 polymorphism (rs116855232) was significantly associated with AZA-induced leukopenia in Chinese patients with AIH and related cirrhosis.

var_pheno_ann.Notes: Among patients in biochemical remission on maintenance therapy, median azathioprine maintenance dose for rs116855232 CT genotype was 0.96 (0.83, 1.19) mg·kg−1·d−1 vs 1.23 (0.95, 1.53) mg·kg−1·d−1 for CC (P = 0.028), indicating CT carriers require lower maintenance doses.
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: rs116855232 CT Is Associated with decreased Other:Dose requirement when treated with azathioprine in people with Autoimmune hepatitis and related cirrhosis.
Citations: In total, 93 patients have achieved biochemical remission and began maintenance therapy as of February 2018. The AZA dose did not significantly differ between CC and CT genotypes (*P* = 0.22) when evaluated with a clinical therapeutic dose of 1.0 mg ⋅ kg^−1^ ⋅ d^−1^. However, the median maintenance dosages for patients with the *NUDT15* CC and CT genotypes were 1.23 (0.95, 1.53) mg ⋅ kg^−1^ ⋅ d^−1^ and 0.96 (0.83, 1.19) mg ⋅ kg^−1^ ⋅ d^−1^, respectively (*P* = 0.028) ([Figure 2](#F2)).

Our results found that the rs116855232 but not the rs1142345 genotype was significantly associated with AZA-induced leukopenia and the maintenance dose in Chinese patients with AIH and related cirrhosis. Safety and efficacy can be maintained in most heterozygous genotype patients on AZA at lower doses of approximately 1 mg ⋅ kg^−1^ ⋅ d^−1^.

We found that a *NUDT15* polymorphism (rs116855232) was significantly associated with AZA-induced leukopenia in Chinese patients with AIH and related cirrhosis. For patients with the heterozygous variants, low-dose AZA (0.96 mg ⋅ kg^−1^ ⋅ d^−1^) is safe for maintaining remission and achieving efficacy comparable to that observed in wild-type patients.

6-Thioguanine nucleotide concentrations for patients with rs116855232 CC and CT genotypes were 145.3(87.4, 199.0) pmol/8 ∗108 RBC and 276.6(150.9, 501.0) pmol/8∗108 RBC, respectively (P = 0.002).

The ratio of AZA dose to 6-TGN concentration for the patients was compared between NUDT15 CC and CT genotypes and the results showed that patients with NUDT15 CT genotypes had much lower values (P = 0.013) (Figure 3).

var_pheno_ann.Notes: No significant association was observed between TPMT*3C rs1142345 genotypes and azathioprine-induced leukopenia in this Chinese AIH cohort (P = 0.283). TPMT*3C alleles were rare (4 carriers out of 149).
var_pheno_ann.Sentence: rs1142345 C Is Not associated with Side Effect:Leukopenia when treated with azathioprine in people with Autoimmune hepatitis and related cirrhosis.
Citations: In contrast, no significant association was observed for TPMT∗3C genotypes.

The gene encoding the TPMT enzyme is highly polymorphic, thus leading to varying levels of enzyme activity in different individuals. However, only approximately 20% of leukopenia cases can be explained by TPMT genetic deficiencies. ... Hence, the lack of significance observed for rs1142345 in the present study is likely due to its low prevalence in East Asian populations and the small sample size of our cohort.

The present study showed a 1.7% frequency of the risk TPMT allele in the analyzed population, which is similar to that reported in other studies involving Chinese IBD patients. This TPMT polymorphism is rare in Asian populations, and the lowest frequencies have been observed in Chinese populations (∼0.9%). ... Hence, the lack of significance observed for rs1142345 in the present study is likely due to its low prevalence in East Asian populations and the small sample size of our cohort.
